metadata.title: Convert Joules to Therms
metadata.description: Convert energy in joules (J) to therms using SI-consistent constants and the US therm definition (100,000 BTU). Includes authoritative notes on variants, precision, and regulatory references.

introduction: This converter translates energy values given in joules (J) into therms using the commonly applied US therm definition (1 therm = 100,000 BTU). Use it for engineering estimates, utility comparisons, and reporting where therms are the required unit.

Values are calculated from standard definitions: the joule is the SI unit of energy and the therm is defined in practice via the British thermal unit (BTU). For regulatory or billing use, confirm whether your context uses the US therm or a regional variant.
methodology: We use established physical constants: 1 BTU = 1,055.05585262 J (NIST reference values). The US therm is defined as 100,000 BTU, so 1 therm = 100,000 × 1,055.05585262 J = 105,505,585.262 J.

Conversion is implemented as a direct fixed-ratio transformation (no iterative methods). For display we round results by default to a sensible number of significant digits but provide exact-step formulas so you can reproduce results to any required precision.
how_is_calculated: Combined formula: therms = joules ÷ 105505585.262. Equivalently, 1 joule = 9.478171e-09 therm (approx.).

faqs.question: Which definition of therm does this converter use?
faqs.answer: This tool uses the US therm definition (1 therm = 100,000 BTU). If you require a different regional definition, verify with your regulator or utility and use the appropriate multiplier.

faqs.question: What constants and references back these numbers?
faqs.answer: The conversion uses the NIST-referenced value for the BTU in joules (1 BTU = 1,055.05585262 J) and the common US therm definition of 100,000 BTU. See NIST and U.S. energy agency references in the citations for authoritative details.

faqs.question: How much precision should I display for reports or billing?
faqs.answer: For billing or regulatory reports, follow the precision requirements of the target agency or utility (often 3–6 significant digits). For scientific calculations keep track of measurement uncertainty and round only in final reporting.

faqs.question: Are there other therm variants I should be aware of?
faqs.answer: Yes. Different jurisdictions or historical sources may use alternative definitions (for example, therm of 100 kBtu vs metric-adapted variants). Always confirm the required definition with the recipient of your data.

faqs.question: Can I trust direct conversions for energy-efficiency compliance?
faqs.answer: Direct unit conversions are mathematically reliable, but compliance also depends on measurement method, instrument calibration, and whether the regulator accepts the unit definition. Keep calibration certificates and reference the authoritative constants when submitting results.

faqs.question: How does instrument uncertainty affect converted values?
faqs.answer: Instrument uncertainty propagates through the conversion linearly. If your energy meter has ±1% uncertainty, converted therm values carry the same relative uncertainty. Document uncertainty and include it in final reporting where required.
